cms:page.cms:title: KVM: Kernel-based Virtual Machine for Linux

cms:content.p: KVM (for Kernel-based Virtual Machine) is a full virtualization solution for Linux on x86 hardware. It consists of a loadable kernel module (kvm.ko) and a userspace component.
Using KVM, one can run multiple virtual machines running unmodified Linux or Windows images. Each virtual machine has private virtualized hardware: a network card, disk, graphics adapter, etc.
The kernel component of KVM is proposed for inclusion into mainline Linux.

Currently, KVM is very stable (at least with the guests we test :), and is fast enough for desktop use on recent processors. For server workloads, an optimized version of the MMU virtualization is needed. This is currently in progress.

KVM is available as a patch to recent Linux kernel versions and as an external module that can be used with your favorite distro- provided kernel. We are working to merge KVM into Linux so that the functionality is available with no hassle.

Working:
Intel-based hosts (requires VT capable processors)
Linux guests (32-bit and 64-bit)
Windows guests (32-bit)
SMP hosts

In progress:
AMD-based hosts (require AMD-V capable processors)
Optimized MMU virtualization

cms:page.name: howto
cms:page.cms:title: Getting KVM to run on your machine

cms:content.p:
You will need:
kvm-module.tar.gz (FIXME: link)
libkvm.tar.gz (FIXME: link)
qemu-0.8.2 (FIXME: link)
qemu-kvm.patch (FIXME: link)
The kvm patchset (FIXME: link)
A VT capable Intel processor
qemu prerequisites:
gcc 3.x
SDL libraries and headers
zlib libraries and headers

Steps:
Compile and load kvm.ko. This assumes you are using the external module:
tar xzf kvm-module.tar.gz cd kvm-module make insmod kvm.ko
Compile and install libkvm:
tar xzf libkvm.tar.gz cd libkvm make sudo make install
Patch, configure, compile, and install qemu:
tar xzf qemu-0.8.2.tar.gz cd qemu-0.8.2 patch -p0 < ../qemu-kvm.patch ./configure --cc=gcc32 --enable-kvm --disable-kqemu --prefix=/usr/local/kvm make sudo make install cd ..
Create a disk image:
/usr/local/kvm/bin/qemu-img create -f qcow vdisk.img 10G
Install an operating system:
/usr/local/kvm/bin/qemu-system-x86_64 \ -hdc vdisk.img \ -cdrom /path/to/boot-media.iso \ -boot d \ -m 384 -net
After installation is complete, run it with:
/usr/local/kvm/bin/qemu-system-x86_64 \ -hdc vdisk.img \ -boot c \ -m 384 -net
